Efficient bifunctional urea–phosphonium halide catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides Bo Liu Writing – review & editing Methodology Investigation a b Xin Zou Writing – review & editing a Zhenjiang Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ Ping Chen Writing – review & editing b Shengxin Chen Writing – review & editing b Xin Yuan Investigation a Yongzhu Hu Investigation a Yanqi Shi Investigation a Ziqi Liu Investigation a Kai Guo Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, 30 Puzhu Road South, Nanjing 211816, China State Key Laboratory Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University 30 Puzhu Road South Nanjing 211816 China aState Key Laboratory Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, 30 Puzhu Road South, Nanjing 211816, China b Sinopec Ningbo New Materials Research Institute Company Limited, Ningbo 315207, China Sinopec Ningbo New Materials Research Institute Company Limited Ningbo 315207 China bSinopec Ningbo New Materials Research Institute Company Limited, Ningbo 315207, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) reaction is one of the few chemical processes viable commercially in the valorization of CO2. A bifunctional urea–phosphonium halide with both electrophilic and nucleophilic centers was proposed as an effective catalyst for CCE reactions here. The urea–phosphonium halides with different urea substituents and halide anions were simply synthesized and systematically evaluated in CCE reactions. It was found that the H-bond donicity of the urea N–Hs, the nucleophilicity of the halide anion, and the affinity between the urea and halide anions jointly affected the catalytic activity of the urea–phosphonium halide in CCE reactions. The H-bonding strength between the N–Hs and nucleophilic anions was disclosed via NMR titrations. The catalyst featuring a 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl-substituted urea structure and an iodide anion was selected as the optimal structure, which promoted the cycloaddition of styrene oxide with excellent conversion (92 %) and selectivity (99 %) in 6 h under mild conditions (1 mol% catalyst loading, 100 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2). Furthermore, the bifunctional catalyst performed exceptional recyclability, exhibiting no discernible decline in catalytic activity over five consecutive reaction cycles. The structure−performance relationship of the urea–phosphonium halides and a wide range of substrates applicability provided valuable insights for the optimization of the existing catalysts or the further design of new effective organocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Urea–phosphonium halides with tunable structures, compromised of the urea N–Hs donicity, the nucleophilicity of halide anions, and the binding strength between urea N–Hs and halide anions, effectively promoted the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides under mild conditions. Keywords Bifunctional organocatalysis CO2 Cyclic carbonate Epoxide Phosphonium halide Urea Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The chemical transformation of carbon dioxide (CO2), which can fix waste CO2 into value-added chemicals, has received increasing attention for reducing the accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere and mitigating climate change [1–3]. However, due to the thermodynamic constraints [4,5] and kinetic hindrance [6] of CO2, a large energy input is a prerequisite for its transformation. A viable approach for CO2 utilization involves its reaction with energetic reactants to overcome the high energy barrier, coupled with efficient catalysts to lower the activation energy [7,8]. The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) affording organic cyclic carbonates [9,10] stands out as a feasible and atom-economic method. These cyclic carbonates are extensively applied as green solvents [11], electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries [12,13], and raw materials of polycarbonates [14]. Numerous catalysts, either metal-based catalysts [15,16] or metal-free organocatalysts [17–20], have been developed in CCE reactions. Non-covalent H-bonding organocatalysts were widely introduced to promote the coupling of CO2 and epoxides owing to their variety of catalyst designs and unique capacity to activate epoxides [21,22]. The application of H-bonding catalysts in CCE reactions was first systematically investigated by Kleij et al. [23], where the polyphenols activated the epoxides as H-bond donors (HBDs) and the co-catalytic ammonium halides attacked the activated epoxides for ring opening. Encouraged by the pioneering work, a series of HBDs in binary or one-component bifunctional catalysts were extensively reported, and the excellent examples could be found in the research of Kleij [24,25], North [26,27], Werner [28,29]; Zhang [30,31], Sun [32,33], and others [34–36]. Our group also made significant efforts in developing H-bonding catalysts for CCE reactions, including N–H HBDs of the amide-functionalized ammonium halides [37], non-classical C–H HBDs of tertiary sulfonium halides [38] and cyclopropenium halides [39], the hybrid HBDs of nicotinamide onium halides [40], and the halide-free HBD-based catalysts such as pyridinium saccharinates [41], squaramide–phenolates [42], and conjugate-acid hydroxy carboxylates [43]. Although the various H-bond donors developed in the cycloaddition have greatly narrowed the gap between the metal-free catalysis and metallic systems, it remained challenging to promote the CCE reactions under low CO2 pressure (0.1 MPa) and low temperature (≤ 100 °C). One-component bifunctional HBD/onium halide catalysts were generally considered to significantly improve the reactivity of CCE reactions [28,29,44–46], (Scheme 1 , A). The bifunctional phosphonium halides functionalized with different HBDs were outstanding among the reported bifunctional catalysts, which could effectively promote the fixation of CO2 by epoxides. The phosphonium halides modified by alcohols were first developed for CCE reactions [28] (Scheme 1, B, i), and the catalytic activity was much higher than the corresponding monofunctional phosphonium halides. The phosphonium halides containing carboxyl or amino groups promoted the cycloaddition reaction under high temperature and high pressure [47] (Scheme 1, B, ii). The H-bond donicity of phenols is stronger than alcohols, and the phenol-based biphenyl quaternary phosphonium catalyst promoted the cycloaddition of CO2 under milder conditions [48] (Scheme 1, B, iii). The phenol-modified tetraarylphosphonium halide also catalyzed the cycloaddition of CO2 under mild conditions [49] (Scheme 1, B, iv), and the introduction of electron-donating groups (such as the methoxy group) on the benzene ring significantly enhanced its catalytic activity [50]. Other phenol-containing phosphonium halide catalysts were also reported for CCE reactions [29,51] (Scheme 1, B, v), as well as the polystyrene- and silica gel-supported ones [52]. Overall, the research on bifunctional phosphonium halides with suitable H-bond donors holds great value for the further design of highly active homogeneous organocatalysts for the chemical fixation of CO2. (Thio)urea derivatives have attracted extensive interest in organic synthesis due to their simple preparation process and the ability to activate substrates through bidentate H-bonding (N–Hs) [53]. Both the (thio)urea-based binary [54] and bifunctional catalysis [31,32,35,55], have been successfully employed in the CCE reactions. The (thio)urea-modified bifunctional phosphonium catalysts were reported to effectively promote the Mannich reaction [56,57], aza-Henry reaction [58], Strecker reaction [59], etc. To our knowledge, their application in CO2 cycloaddition has not been systematically studied except for one work on the mechanistic investigation by theoretical calculations [60]. Moreover, the catalytic activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 was not positively correlated with the donicity of the HBD, and the urea derivatives with weaker H-bond donicity probably performed higher activity than thioureas owing to the weaker unfavorable H-bond binding between N–Hs and halide anions [61,62]. In this work, a bifunctional urea–phosphonium catalyst was introduced for the CCE reactions (Scheme 1, B, vi), and the reaction was effectively conducted with low catalyst loading under solvent-free and mild conditions. A series of urea–phosphonium halides with variable nucleophilic anions and substituents were simply prepared for the CCE reactions. The influence of catalyst structure on the activity of the CCE reactions was systematically studied via 1H NMR experiments, which was expected to facilitate the in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanism and the future catalyst design. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials CO2 was supplied by Nanjing Shangyuan Industrial Gas Factory with a purity of 99.99 %. Epoxides were purchased from Alfa Aesar. Isocyanates, benzyl chloride, and benzyl bromide were supplied by Energy Chemical. Benzyl iodide was purchased from Leyan, and 2-(diphenylphosphino)ethylamine was purchased from Aladdin. All other reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Characterizations NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 MHz and 100 MHz NMR spectrometer in CDCl3 or DMSO‑d 6 as stated deuterated solvents. Chemical shifts δ are reported in parts per million (ppm) using CDCl3 or DMSO‑d 6 as the solvent references (1H NMR: δ 7.26 ppm for CDCl3, δ 2.50 ppm for DMSO‑d 6; 13C NMR δ 77.16 ppm for CDCl3, δ 39.52 ppm for DMSO‑d 6). The catalysts were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, 19F NMR, and 31P NMR spectroscopy with DMSO‑d 6 as the solvent. The products were characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy with CDCl3 as the solvent. The conversions and selectivities of epoxides were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy with CDCl3 as the solvent. High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) was performed using an Ionspec 7.0 T spectrometer. 2.3 General procedure for the synthesis of catalysts 1a, 1b, and 1d–1l [58,63] The 2-(diphenylphosphino)ethylamine (229.26 mg, 1.0 mmol) and 2 mL of dichloromethane (DCM) were charged in a 10 mL vial. Subsequently, the substituted isocyanates (1.1 mmol) were added dropwise. The obtained yellowy transparent solution was stirred at room temperature for 4–8 h. Excess n-hexane was added into the reaction mixture generating a suspension. The supernatant was removed by centrifugation, yielding a white or yellowish solid. The solid was washed three times with n-hexane and then dried under vacuum. The produced solid (1.0 mmol) was subsequently dissolved in 5 mL of toluene in a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, and the benzyl halide (1.2 mmol) was added. The mixture was refluxed at 110 °C for 8 h and then cooled to room temperature. Excess n-hexane was added into the flask forming a suspension. The crude products were generated by centrifugation for removing the supernatant. And the collected crude product was washed three times with n-hexane and dried under vacuum to obtain a white or yellow product. Yield: 61–76 %. 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis of catalysts 1c and 1m The catalyst 1b (655.42 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of acetone in a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, and a solution of sodium iodide (179.87 mg, 1.2 mmol) or sodium hexafluorophosphate (201.54 mg, 1.2 mmol) in 2 mL of acetone was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The sodium bromide precipitate was filtered off, and the acetone in filtrate was removed under vacuum. After that, 20 mL of DCM was added to wash the crude products, and the precipitate was removed by filtration as well. DCM was removed in vacuo to afford a white solid, which was dried overnight under vacuum. Yield: 89 % for 1c and 84 % for 1m. 2.5 General procedure for the synthesis of PPh3Bn·Br and PPh3Bn·I The benzyl bromide (0.12 mL, 1 mmol) or benzyl iodide (218.04 mg, 1 mmol) was added to a 5 mL vial and dissolved with 0.12 mL of benzene, and the triphenylphosphine (314.75 mg, 1.2 mmol) was subsequently added. The mixture was stirred overnight at 80 °C, and the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with benzene (2 × 2 mL). A solid product was obtained after drying overnight under vacuum. Yield: 84 % for PPh3Bn·Br (white solid) and 87 % for PPh3Bn·I (light-yellow solid). 2.6 General procedure for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide (CCE) The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) reactions were conducted in a 10 mL Schlenk flask. After Schlenk operations, the water- and oxygen-free Schlenk flask was ready for use. The inert gas used was argon. The phosphonium halide catalysts and epoxides were added to the flask in order under an argon atmosphere. The argon in the flask was subsequently replaced by CO2. Then, the flask was put into the oil bath and equipped with a CO2 balloon. In a typical procedure, the Schlenk flask was charged with catalyst 1c (35.12 mg, 0.05 mmol) and styrene oxide (0.6 mL, 5 mmol). The flask was subsequently inserted by a CO2 balloon and put into the oil bath under 100 °C for reaction. The conversions of epoxides were determined by 1H NMR spectra using CDCl3 as solvent, and 1H NMR yields of cyclic carbonates were determined with 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane as the internal standard. The reaction mixture was cooled in ice prior to sampling for 1H NMR spectra measurements. Pure carbonates were obtained by column chromatography with an eluent of petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (5:1). The structures of the carbonates were characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR using CDCl3 as solvent. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Design of the urea–phosphonium halides and evaluation of catalytic performance in CCE reactions (Thio)urea was one of the most widely reported H-bond donor (HBD) catalysts due to its simplified preparation procedure and bidentate H-bonding activation [53]. The bifunctional urea–phosphonium halide contained both an HBD (the urea moiety) and a nucleophilic site (the halide anion), making it potential candidates for promoting the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) reactions through the synergistic interactions of the urea in activating epoxides and the halide in attacking the urea-coordinated epoxides. A series of urea–phosphonium halides (1a–m) were synthesized and evaluated for sufficient insight into their ability in catalyzing the CCE reactions. The initial experiment was performed under the conditions of 120 °C and 1 atm CO2 using styrene oxide (SO) as a typical substrate with 1 mol% catalyst loading without solvent for 4 h, serving as a benchmark CCE reaction. Before implementations of the urea–phosphonium halides, the control CCE reaction of SO and CO2 without any catalyst was conducted (Table 1 , entry 1), and no conversion of SO to the styrene carbonate (SC) was observed, meaning that the background formation of cyclic organic carbonate was negligible. The catalytic activity of urea–phosphonium halides showed significant differences depending on the counter anions and the urea structure (Fig. 1 ). The stronger H-bond donicity of urea usually meant that it could activate epoxides more effectively, but the urea with stronger H-bond donicity would bind with halide anions more tightly and reduce the reactivity of CCE reactions. The higher nucleophilicity of halide anion often led to higher conversion of epoxide as the monofunctional catalysts employed, that is Cl– > Br– > I –, which would be changed in bifunctional catalysts due to the H-bond interactions of HBD and halide anions increased with nucleophilicity of the latter [28]. In vertical comparisons based on the different urea structures, the catalysts modified by the urea with strong or moderate H-bond donicity (1a–i) performed the reactivity in the order of I– > Br– > Cl– (Table 1, entries 2–10), which was opposite to the nucleophilicity order of anions and might be attributed to the strong H-bond binding between the halide anions and the urea. The different H-bonding between the urea and halide anions could be confirmed by 1H NMR spectra of catalysts 1a–c. As shown in Fig. 2 , the signals of N–Hs on the urea lacking a phosphonium center were observed at 6.671 and 9.327 ppm, and they were gradually shifted to downfield in the urea–phosphonium halides following the order of I– (1c, 6.741 and 9.480 ppm) < Br– (1b, 6.878 and 9.718 ppm) < Cl– (1a, 7.209 and 10.359 ppm), which indicated that the interaction between Cl– and the urea N–Hs was the strongest among these three halide anions in 1a–c. In the catalysts 1j–l, which were modified with the urea of weak H-bond donicity, the bromide 1k promoted a more active CCE reaction than chloride 1j and iodide 1l (Table 1, entries 11–13). The H-bond binding strength of the N–Hs and halide anions in 1j–l was also studied by 1H NMR spectra (Fig. 3 ), and the differences in chemical shifts among 1j–l was lower than that in 1a–c owing to the weak H-bond donicity, where the influence of the H-bonding between N–Hs and halide anions on catalytic activity was weakened. The chemical shifts of N–Hs on catalyst 1k (Br–, 6.078 and 6.088 ppm) and 1l (I–, 5.994 and 6.045 ppm) were close, which meant that the Br– and I– showed similar H-bonding strength with the urea N–Hs, and the stronger nucleophilicity of Br– (1k) than I– (1l) led to the higher catalytic activity. The Cl– (1j, 6.278 and 6.202 ppm) still performed a stronger interaction with the urea structure than Br– and I–, which diminished the positive effect of its high nucleophilicity on catalytic activity. Thus, the catalytic activity of 1j–l followed the order of Br– > I – > Cl– due to the co-dominant effects of the nucleophilicity of halide anions and the interaction between the N–Hs and halide anions, and it was different from that of 1a–i, where the activity was dominated by the H-bonding between urea N–Hs and halide anions. In lateral comparisons based on counter anions, the reactivity of chlorides decreased in the order of 1j > 1g > 1d > 1a as the H-bond donicity of the urea increased, which indicated that the Cl– binding with the urea closely and the binding strength dominated the reactivity. In the reaction catalyzed by bromides, the reactivity was influenced by both the activation of the urea N–Hs on epoxides and the H-bonding between the urea and Br–. The reactivity of bromide 1b that containing the most active urea was not the worst among urea–phosphonium bromides like the analogous chloride 1a, which could presumably be explained by the strong activation of 1b to epoxide offset the unfavorable binding of the urea and Br–. The H-bond interaction of I– and HBD was generally thought to be weak due to the large ionic radius of iodide, which led to the reactivity of iodides was mainly affected by the ability of the urea structure in activating epoxides. Therefore, the stronger H-bond donicity of urea, the stronger epoxide activation through H-bonding, and the higher catalytic activity of the corresponding iodide. The activity of urea–phosphonium iodides followed the order of 1c > 1f > 1i > 1l, which was consistent with the decreasing H-bond donicity of the urea structure. This trend contrasted with that of chlorides, which exhibited strong but unfavorable binding with urea N–Hs. The combination of the urea with strong H-bond donicity and halide anions with strong nucleophilicity often led to overly strong H-bonding between them, and could not promote the CCE reaction as effectively as expected. Therefore, balancing the H-bond donicity of urea structure, the nucleophilicity of halide anion, and the binding strength between urea N–Hs and anions was crucial for the urea–phosphonium halide-catalyzed reactions. Catalyst 1c, featuring with a 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl-substituted urea, promoted the most active CCE reaction (4 h, 88 % conv., 99 % sel.) in iodides. It was also selected as the optimal urea–phosphonium halide catalyst, as its urea moiety performed strong H-bond donicity for effectively activating epoxides, while the weak H-bonding interactions between the urea N–Hs and iodides enabled efficient nucleophilic attack on the epoxides. Compared with the previous bifunctional phosphonium halide catalysts, the urea–phosphonium halides 1c achieved better catalytic performance under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 100 °C) (Table S1). The control experiments were conducted to certify that both the urea structure and halide anion were indispensable. The catalyst 1m featuring a non-nucleophilic counter anion PF6 – was synthesized for the reaction of SO and CO2 (Table 1, entry 14), and only 2 % of SO was converted, which proved that the nucleophilic anion was necessary. Moreover, the chemical shifts of the N–Hs on the urea of 1m were recorded at 6.758 and 9.507 ppm which were similar to those of catalyst 1c (Fig. 2), further proving the weak binding interaction between the urea N–Hs and I–. Monofunctional phosphonium halides (PPh3Bn·Br, PPh3Bn·I, PBu4·I, and PPh4·I) were compared under the benchmark CCE reaction (Table 1, entries 15–18), and their conversion was lower than those of the corresponding urea-based analogues. It was reasonable to conclude that an appropriate urea structure for activating epoxides was important to CCE reactions. 3.2 Influence of temperature, catalyst loading, and reaction time on the CCE reactions The effect of temperature and catalyst loading on the conversion of styrene oxide was studied by employing the optimal catalyst 1c. When lowering the temperature from 120 °C to 80 °C (Table 2 , entries 1 and 3), the conversion of SO gradually decreased from 88 % to 62 %. The reaction was also attempted at room temperature (ca. 25 °C), unfortunately, only 4 % of SO was converted into styrene carbonate (Table 2, entry 4). The lower reaction temperature of 100 °C was selected as the preferred temperature due to the similar conversion to that at 120 °C (Table 2, entries 1 and 2, 83 % vs. 88 %). At 100 °C, a sharp decrease in conversion from 88 % to 9 % was observed by lowering the catalyst loading from 1 mol% to 0.1 mol% (Table 2, entries 2 and 5–7). Increasing the catalyst loading to 2 mol%, the SO could be converted into SC with higher conversion of 96 % in 4 h (Table 2, entry 8). For economic considerations, the catalyst loading of 1 mol% was thought to be more suitable. With 1 mol% loading of 1c, the conversions of SO could increase to 92 % and 97 % by prolonging reaction times to 6 h and 8 h (Table 2, entries 9 and 10), which indicated that extending the reaction time was beneficial for enhancing the conversion of epoxides. However, the conversion of SO reached a plateau after 8 h, and just slightly increased to 98 % in a longer time of 10 h (Table 2, entry 11). The temperature of 100 °C and the catalyst loading of 1 mol% were selected as the optimal conditions for subsequent studies, and the reaction time was adjusted for different epoxide substrates to achieve quantitative conversion. 3.3 Substrate scope of epoxides in cycloadditions with CO2 catalyzed by catalyst 1c Under the optimal conditions, epoxides with different substituents were employed to evaluate the substrate scope of catalyst 1c in CCE reactions. Glycidyl 2-methylphenyl ether and phenyl glycidyl ether required an extended time of 6 h to reach approximately 90 % conversions like the styrene oxide (Table 3 , entries 7 and 8). 2-(4-Chlorophenyl)oxirane and allyl glycidyl ether achieved approximately 90 % conversions with longer reaction times of 8 h and 10 h (Table 3, entries 9 and 10). Other less hindered epoxides afforded nearly quantitative conversions (90–96 %) with 99 % selectivity in 4 h with high TOFs (> 22 h–1) (Table 3, entries 1–6), regardless of their different substituents. Internal epoxides, such as cyclohexene oxide and stilbene oxide, which were generally difficult to activate [25,64], resulted in low conversions under these conditions even with an extended reaction time of 12 h (Table 3, entries 11 and 12). 3.4 Proposition and validation of the mechanism of the CCE reaction catalyzed by urea–phosphonium halide catalysts Control experiments proved that the urea structure and the nucleophilic halide anions were both indispensable for efficient cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. In order to further validate the activating role of the urea structure on the epoxide, 1H and 13C NMR titration experiments of 1c on styrene oxide were carried out. The chemical shift of the methine hydrogen on SO shifted upfield from 3.918 to 3.900 ppm as the ratios of 1c to SO increased from 0.03/1 to 1/1 (Fig. 4 ). The shielding effect of the methine proton in SO indicated the H-bonding between oxygen atom of SO and the urea structure of 1c. Accordingly, the signal peaks of N–Hs on catalyst 1c showed downfield shifts from 9.491 and 6.754 ppm to 9.535 and 6.789 ppm in the same series of 1c/SO titrations, which implied that the N–Hs of 1c were deshielded due to the electron-withdrawing effect of the oxygen of SO. 13C NMR titration experiments also verified the H-bonding between catalyst 1c and SO (Fig. 5 ). The chemical shifts of the methine carbon on SO shifted upfield from 51.527 to 51.485 ppm with increasing ratios of 1c/SO from 0.03/1 to 1/1, and the signal of the carbonyl carbon on 1c showed a similar upfield shift (from 154.706 to 154.665 ppm). These NMR titration experiments collectively supported the coordination between the urea N–Hs on catalyst 1c and the oxygen atom of SO through H-bonds. Based on the previous studies [28,29,49], and the experimental results, a plausible mechanism of the CCE reaction catalyzed by urea–phosphonium halide 1c was proposed Scheme 2 . The bidentate urea N−Hs coordinated with the oxygen atom of SO for activating the epoxide via H-bonding (step I). The nucleophilic iodide anion (I–) then attacked the methylene carbon of the activated epoxide, opening the epoxide ring and forming an alkoxide anion, which was stabilized by H-bonding (step II). Subsequently, the alkoxide added to the electrophilic carbon of CO2, generating a carbonate anion that also coordinated with N−Hs (step III). Finally, the carbonate anion intramolecularly nucleophilic attacked the methine carbon for ring-closure, releasing the cyclic carbonate product and regenerating catalyst 1c for next catalytic cycle (step IV). 3.5 Investigation of the catalyst recyclability of the urea–phosphonium halide catalysts The recyclability of catalysts is important for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. The reusability of urea–phosphonium halides was systematically investigated under the optimized reaction conditions (100 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure, 1 mol% of 1c, 4 h) using epichlorohydrin (ECH) as the substrate. The recycling procedure of the catalyst is outlined as follows: (1) urea–phosphonium halide 1c was initially employed as the catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of ECH and CO2; (2) the reaction mixture was sampled after 4 h for monitoring ECH conversions via ¹H NMR spectroscopy; (3) the catalyst 1c was separated from the reaction products by Kugelrohr distillation; and (4) the recovered catalyst was reused under the same optimized conditions. Remarkably, the catalytic performance demonstrated consistent excellence across five consecutive cycles (Fig. 6 ), and over 90 % of ECH was converted to the corresponding cyclic carbonate without any discernible decline in activity. The slight differences of conversions could be attributed to detection errors. The notable recyclability of the urea–phosphonium halide catalyst underscored its practical potential for sustainable catalytic applications. 4 Conclusions Carbon fixation by the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) reaction to produce commercial cyclic carbonates is one of the few processes viable at the industrial scale for non-reductive valorization of CO2 [10,65]. Herein, a bifunctional urea–phosphonium halide catalyst bearing bidentate N–H H-bond donors (HBDs) was proposed and evaluated in the CCE reaction. The H-bond donicity of the urea N–Hs, the nucleophilicity of the halide anion, and the interaction between the urea and halide anions jointly affected the catalytic activity of the urea–phosphonium halide in CCE reactions. The activity of the catalyst containing the urea structure with strong or moderate H-bond donicity was inversely proportional to the nucleophilicity of the halide anions, that is I– > Br– > Cl–, which was different from the monofunctional phosphonium halides. And it was probably due to the unfavorable H-bond interactions of the urea and halide anions increased with nucleophilicity. The bromide in the series of catalysts with a weak H-bond donicity urea showed the best catalytic activity because of the compromise between the nucleophilicity of halide anions and the binding interaction of anions with urea N–Hs. The strength of H-bond interactions of halide anions with the strong H-bond donicity urea (substituted by 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl, 1a–c) and the weak H-bond donicity urea (substituted by cyclohexyl, 1j–l) was compared via 1H NMR. Iodide catalyst bearing the 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl-substituted urea (1c) presented the best catalytic activity under the optimal conditions of 1 mol% catalyst loading and temperature of 100 °C, and the differently substituted epoxides were converted into corresponding cyclic carbonate in 10 h with the conversion over 90 % except the internal epoxides. Control experiments and NMR titration experiments proved that both the HBD urea and halide anions were necessary in the catalytic cycle, while the N–Hs activated epoxides and the nucleophilic halide attacked the activated epoxides. Recyclability study of the catalyst 1c supported that the urea–phosphonium halides could be well reused and developed for sustainable catalytic applications. The influence of different substituents of urea and halide anions on the catalytic performance was studied for providing guidance for the design of new catalyst. The urea–phosphonium halides were only effective for the conversion of terminal epoxides under mild conditions, further works in catalyzing both terminal and internal epoxides under mild conditions are in progress. coredata.dc:description: The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (CCE) reaction is one of the few chemical processes viable commercially in the valorization of CO2. A bifunctional urea–phosphonium halide with both electrophilic and nucleophilic centers was proposed as an effective catalyst for CCE reactions here. The urea–phosphonium halides with different urea substituents and halide anions were simply synthesized and systematically evaluated in CCE reactions. It was found that the H-bond donicity of the urea N–Hs, the nucleophilicity of the halide anion, and the affinity between the urea and halide anions jointly affected the catalytic activity of the urea–phosphonium halide in CCE reactions. The H-bonding strength between the N–Hs and nucleophilic anions was disclosed via NMR titrations. The catalyst featuring a 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl-substituted urea structure and an iodide anion was selected as the optimal structure, which promoted the cycloaddition of styrene oxide with excellent conversion (92 %) and selectivity (99 %) in 6 h under mild conditions (1 mol% catalyst loading, 100 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2). Furthermore, the bifunctional catalyst performed exceptional recyclability, exhibiting no discernible decline in catalytic activity over five consecutive reaction cycles. The structure−performance relationship of the urea–phosphonium halides and a wide range of substrates applicability provided valuable insights for the optimization of the existing catalysts or the further design of new effective organocatalysts.
